awd_abstract_narration:
Distributed algorithms underlie the efficient operation of large-scale  communication networks, e.g., distributed shortest paths algorithms are used for routing in the Internet. Two fundamental performance measures of distributed algorithms are the running time and the number of messages used  by the algorithm. Research in the last three decades has focused to a large extent on optimizing  either one of the two measures separately, typically at the cost of the other. This project investigates how distributed algorithms can be designed to work well under both measures simultaneously. This may have significant implications in many emerging applications,  especially in the context of large-scale distributed communication networks and distributed processing of large-scale data.


The project studies time-message tradeoffs in distributed algorithms for various specific fundamental problems, such as leader election, shortest paths,  minimum spanning tree construction, and random walks. These are fundamental primitives in distributed computing where optimizing both time and messages simultaneously has so far been elusive. Specific goals of the project are to: (1) design distributed algorithms that are optimal with respect to the other measure when given a particular value of one measure;  (2) obtain lower bounds on the complexity of one measure while fixing the other measure; (3) obtain  tradeoff relationships that characterizes the dependence of one measure on the other; and (4) obtain efficient distributed algorithms that operate on large-scale graphs. This research will yield efficient and scalable distributed algorithms with provable performance guarantees. This project could potentially impact algorithm design in real-world distributed networks and distributed computations over large-scale data. The project trains students and postdoctoral fellows to tackle research problems in distributed algorithms.

por.por_cntn:
The results of this project has significantly advanced our ability to design provably good distributed  algorithms that are efficient with respect to both time and communication (number of messages). Distributed algorithms underlie the operation of modern communication networks including the Internet, wireless and sensor networks, and peer-to-peer networks with numerous applications including blockchain technologies. Efficient distributed graph algorithms are also important  for fast distributed processing of big graph data.

Intellectual Merit: The project has resulted in the design  and analysis of new and efficient distributed algorithms  for several fundamental distributed graph problems including  leader election, minimum spanning tree (MST), maximal independent set (MIS), coloring  and ruling sets. These problems have been extensively studied in the last four decades and have applications to important networking tasks including broadcast, coordination, routing, and interference control. These algorithms are also important in the distributed computation of large-scale graph problems.  

An important contribution of the project is the development of so-called singularly optimal algorithms, i.e., algorithms that are simultaneously optimal with respect to both time and messages. The project resulted in the design and analysis of the first-known (almost) singularly optimal algorithms for leader election and minimum spanning trees.  Another major contribution of the project is deriving message-time tradeoffs and message lower bounds for various fundamental problems. Our work on time-message tradeoffs gives a deeper understanding of what is best possible with respect to both message and time complexity for distributed algorithms.

The project also introduced the sleeping model for distributed algorithms and the asssociated awake complexity measures which is relevant for designing highly energy-efficient distributed algorithms. It showed that the fundamental MIS problem can be solved in constant round node-averaged awake complexity. This means that a node spends only very small (constant) amount of energy during the course of the algorithm.

 

Broader Impacts: 

Computing with `Big Data" is one of the important cornerstones of modern computing, and ``Big Graph Data" is especially important with the rise of large-scale graph data. The development of efficient distributed algorithms for fundamental graph problems will have a direct impact in designing efficient distributed algorithms for large-scale graphs.  The techniques introduced in this project has led to new lower bounds for message complexity in distributed algorithms (e.g., for MIS, coloring, ruling sets,  leader election, and MST) and also spurred interest in message-efficient distributed algorithms. Previously, much of the focus had been mostly on time-efficient algorithms while ignoring message complexity. However, both time and message complexity is important in modern applications such as resource-constrained networks and distributed computation of large-scale data. Our work introduced the awake complexity of distributed algorithms that has spurred interest in designing distributed algorithms that are efficient with respect to energy. These have the potential to impact algorithms for ad hoc wireless and sensor networks.

The results of this project have been published in top peer-reviewed conferences in computer science including STOC, PODC, SPAA, and DISC as well as top-tier journals such as ACM Transactions on Algorithms.

The project has resulted in disseminating the work on distributed algorithms to a more broader audience. This has been done by several talks given by the PI and his collaborators in various institutions and workshops. The PI also has published an expository article on singularly optimal algorithms focusing on the fundamental minimum spanning tree problem (including the results of this project) in the EATCS bulletin, a magazine for the European association for theoretical computer science.  The PI has also incorporated the results of this research in his Distributed Algorithms course taught at  the University of Houston and the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) at  Madras.

The project has contributed to opportunities for research and mentoring of four Ph.D. students ---  Soumyottam Chatterjee, Reza Fathi, Nguyen Dinh Pham, Khalid Hourani (all at University of Houston, a minority serving Tier 1 public research institution) and three postdoctoral scholars --- Michele Scquizzato, Robert Gmyr, and William Kumar Moses Jr. (all at University of Houston).

This NSF-BSF  project has  contributed to collaborations with Israeli collaborators  Prof. David Peleg (Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovat, Israel) and Prof. Shay Kutten (Technion, Haifa, Israel). It also led to collaborations with Prof. Sriram Pemmaraju (University of Iowa) and his Ph.D. student Shreyas Pai and Prof. Peter Robinson (City University of Hong Kong). These collaborations have also resulted in more broadly disseminating the research topics among the researchers in the respective universities.
